item.title: UIKonf 2020 Goes Remote
item.description:
The organizers of UIKonf just announced that this year‚Äôs conference will be remote only due to COVID-19 pandemic. I‚Äôm really glad that they did this to help in the fight against this disease while still allowing the conference to continue. UIKonf has been my favorite tech conference due to it‚Äôs forward thinking and social nature and this year is shaping up to be no different. The best part is now everyone can experience this for themselves for just ‚Ç¨ 100.

Switching formats is not an easy nor inexpensive task, especially when it occurs a little over a month from dates of the conference (May 17 to May 19). As such it‚Äôs very important to the iOS Community, and me personally, that we help the organizers out as best we can so that not only can UIKonf happen in 2020 but that it‚Äôs also able to survive for future years. I‚Äôve been lucky enough to get to know the organizers over the past few years personally and I can understand the pressure they‚Äôre under.

Here‚Äôs some options for how you can help:

  1. Buy a Remote Ticket for ‚Ç¨ 100
  2. Make a Support Donation for ‚Ç¨ 100
  3. If you‚Äôve previously bought a Regular Ticket for ‚Ç¨ 559 tell the organizers that you‚Äôd like to donate the ‚Ç¨ 459 conversion to Remote Ticket rebate that they‚Äôre offering. It‚Äôs what I‚Äôve done already and would happily do again.

item.title: UIKonf 2019 Review
item.description:
This was my second time attending UIKonf in Berlin and it more than lived up to my fondest memories from UIKonf 2018. I was pleasantly surprised by to find the so many people that I‚Äôd met and interacted with the previous year were back again and that they all remembered me! It was truly being back amongst friends‚Ä¶ even after a year‚Äôs time and 4400 miles travelled.

As UIKonf is well known for, the quality and range of topics again this year was no different. Traditionally the conference organizers utilize an anonymous Call For Proposal process to select the talks, but this year decided to have an ‚Äúall-female speaker line up on stage‚Äù. While this caused some consternation when it was announced, by far the feedback that I heard while there and my own personal experience being there was very positive. UIKonf was still UIKonf. I think this was a great experiment and more importantly sets the bar much higher for other tech conferences in having more women as featured speakers going forward. There should be no more excuses. For more details about the reasoning behind this check out Hacking with Swift‚Äôs interview with conference organizer Sabine Geithner.

I‚Äôm already looking forward to attending again next year, but until then please enjoy a few of my favorite presentations from this year:

Shannon Hughes - Detangling Gesture Recognizers

Julie Yaunches - Consistency Principle

Sally Shepard - Swift to Hack Hardware

F√ºsun Wehrmann - From Heroic Leaders To High Performing Teams

Ellen Shapiro - Kotlin/Native

Kate Castellano - What to expect when you are templating? Clue‚Äôs approach to Backend Driven UIs

For more great talks please explore the full UIKonf 2019 Session Playlist.

item.title: Beautiful night along the Spree in Berlin
DotSwift 2019 Review
item.description:
I attended the DotSwift conference in Paris, France the last week of January. It‚Äôs an afternoon of a series of 18 minute talks and 5 ‚Äúlightning talks‚Äù that last 4 minutes all on topics related to Swift software development. This conference brings together people from across Europe and North America and emphasizes presence / social interaction. In fact one of my favorite things about the conferece was it‚Äôs ‚ÄúNo Wifi‚Äù policy. This encouraged attendees and presenters to talk with each other during breaks as well as enable attendees to give their full attention to the presentations.

Here are some of my favorite presentations from the conference:

Daniel Jalkut - Just Enough Objective-C

Discusses how even ‚ÄúPure Swift‚Äù apps live in a world of Objective-C code.

Mark Dalrymple - Wh@t is th@t?

A deep dive into what annotations are, how they work, and most interestly how to find them in the iOS SDK.

Janina Kutyn - CATransform3D: You don‚Äôt need to know them

Fascinating technical details about the math that powers Apple‚Äôs Core Animation APIs.

Soroush Khanlou - From Problem to Solution

A guide on how simplied solutions reveal themselves via iteration and abstraction.

To learn more about the conference make sure to checkout the conference videos and photos.

item.title: Twice Is Nice! Simple Featured Again On Apple App Store
item.description:
This week Apple is (again!) featuring the Simple Finance iOS app as the top budgeting app for college students.

College is an exciting time that often also comes with many new responsiblities, not the least of which is learning how to manage money. This can be a scary and difficult life skill to learn, especially with so many other things happening simulataneously. I‚Äôm really excited to see our team‚Äôs work promoted as a tool for helping college students learn these skills in a safe, straightforward, and simple way.

item.title: Simple Featured On Apple App Store
item.description:
Today the Simple Finance iOS app was featured by Apple on the App Store under the category of ‚ÄúBest New Updates‚Äù.

The entire team at Simple has been heads down this year building and shipping new features for our customers. It‚Äôs incredibly gratifying to be recognized for our work and are thankful for it. You can check these features for yourself by downloading the app and by reading about them on the Simple blog:

  • Simple Expenses
  • Emergency Fund Goal
  • Automated Goals

item.title: Tracking My Car's Mileage With Fuel App
item.description:
tl;dr: I built (and open sourced) an iPhone X app to track my car‚Äôs fuel usage.

Background

I bought my current car in 2016 (Volkswagen Jetta ‚ù§Ô∏è) and was interested in knowing how long (if at all) the advertised fuel efficicany of the car held up. To do this I‚Äôve been recording the mileage everytime I stop to refuel. I have done this manually by recording the trip odometer, the amount of gas bought, what type of gas bought, etc and then entering it into a spreadsheet at home since I bought the car. I‚Äôve now been able to automate this process by creating an app for my personal iPhone X.

Introducting Fuel

Fuel is an app that allows me to record all the relevant fuel stop data while I‚Äôm at the gas station and then persist the data securely and privately in CloudKit. This is such a time saver in addition to helping avoid forgetting to enter data at a later date. It also lets me access these fuel stop records so I can track and compare the data over time.

Tech Used

I really like to explore new tools, libraries, and frameworks when I‚Äôm building personal projects and this was project was no different. This time out I got to work with RxSwift, CloudKit, and Carthage to name a few. In addition to those tools for the app I also got to dive deeper on using mock objects in Swift to test architectural patterns as well the asychronous actions of RxSwift with XCTest

Source Code Available

While I‚Äôm handling distribution of the app to select devices via TestFlight and not publishing this app publically on the App Store, I am happy to make the source code available for others to see.

https://github.com/bleege/Fuel

item.title: UIKonf 2018 Review
item.description:
tl;dr: A collection of my favorite presentations from UIKonf, an independent technical and community conference for iOS developers.

I had the great pleasure to attend UIKonf in Berlin, Germany last week. It was a single track conference over two days that had a great balance of technical, business, and socially positive presentations. I really enjoyed getting to meet and learn from some incredible people from around the world. Here are some of my favorite presentations:

Kamilah Taylor - Tired of the state of online conversations? üôàüôâüôä Let‚Äôs do something about it üí™

A fantastic look at how today‚Äôs social media platforms‚Äô internal business measures of success encourage the polarization, misinformation, and distrust we‚Äôre seeing in society. More importantly, what people are starting to do to fix these problems.

John Sundell - The Magic of UI Testing

Great advice on how to find the right balance between test coverage, utility, and speed.

Carola Nitz - Advanced Debugging Techniques

A deep dive on some (not widely known) tools and techniques for finding and fixing issues with UIs and performance.

Dave DeLong - The Laws of Magic

A brand new talk from Dave where he discusses 3 ‚Äúlaws‚Äù for building engaging experiences and apps.

Janina Kutyn - Improving Scrolling Performance through GPU Optimisation

An introduction to how device CPU and GPU work together to produce smooth UIs and how you can improve their collaboration for your app.

Vincent Garrigues - Scaling iOS, a story of technical debt, and how to get through it

A story about the unitended consquences of rewriting the SoundCloud app, what the team learned from this experience, and how they used what they learned to succeed.

The entire set of conference presentations are also available on YouTube.

item.title: Making Location Edits To Apple Maps
item.description:
tl;dr: Apple accepts location data additions and edits for Apple Maps via macOS Maps app.

As a traveler one of my favorite features about macOS Photos app is the map view that displays the location of each of my photos. I love how this helps me remember my past travels as well as provides inspiration for places I have yet to visit. Recently I imported some travel photos that did not have geolocation information needed to power the map display. In order to get these photos to display on the map I had to geocode each photo. While doing so I discovered several locations that Apple Maps didn‚Äôt currently have. macOS Photos‚Äôs map works just fine with raw latitude / longitude coordinates for the photos but Apple Maps is much richer for all of us to have the locations labeled. Thankfully Apple has a way to do this.

S√∏fartsmonumentet

One such location is the S√∏fartsmonumentet in Copenhagen, Denmark. It‚Äôs a memorial built after World War I and features the Greek goddess Nike. It is located near the more famous Little Mermaid statue on the harbor.

Adding The Location

The first thing to do is to find and then mark the location on the map. This is done via Control clicking on the point where the new location should appear.

Drop Pin

Marked Location

Access To Location Data Editor

From the new pin tap the Info button to display the information Popover. The ‚ÄúReport Issue‚Äù button is located at the bottom of the Popover and is what opens the location data editor.

Information Popover

Open Location Data Editor via Report Issue button

Create The Location Edits

From the location data editor sheet are options available for creating the location edits. In this case ‚ÄúAdd A Place‚Äù is selected and the subsequent step by step workflow is followed through to it‚Äôs conclusion‚Ä¶ Send to Apple!

Location Data Editor Sheet

Add Location Editor Final Step

Follow Up

Apple then usually takes about a week to review submissions and if they accept them then sends a notification to you via your Apple ID connected devices. From there I‚Äôve noticed that it usually takes another couple of weeks before the basemap is updated and shows the location.

Newly Added Location Popover

Newly Added Location On Basemap

Happy Mapping!
